params.text:
Preparing the loom

            “Dressing the loom “is the term used to describe the process of preparing the loom for weaving.
 

Many important processes must be completed before the actual weaving can begin. Many preparatory steps are necessary, beginning with the preparation of the warp and continuing through the winding of shuttles. The logical sequences of those steps are as follow;

  1. Preparation of the warp
  2. Warping the beam
  3. Threading and sleying
  4. Tying the warp ends onto the cloth-beam rod
  5. The tie-up
  6. Preparing the shuttles
  7. Testing the loom
  8. Weaving
  9. Finishing ends of web and removal from loom

metadata.title: Sequence steps for preparing the loom

params.text:
Preparation of the warp. Determine the number of warp threads needed to weave a web or piece of material at a given width.

Steps;
1. Insert the threads into the reed a comb-like structure that separates the warps threads and helps keep them in order
2. After inserting the threads into the reed, pull all the threads into the wrapping frames to determine the thinness or thickness of the textile to be woven.
3. When the warps have been determined the thickness you should remove them into the warping frame.

params.text: Threading and Sleying

This method is for two people who work together. One sits at the back through the unattached string heddle, and the other at the front. The person at the front of the detached stringed heddle needs the pattern and is assisted by the person at the back of the unattached stringed heddle in finding the correct heddle through which to thread the warp end.

The arranged warp yarn needs to be individually inserted into each eye of the stringed heddle and then into each slat of the reed. It is advisable for the person at the back to copy the pattern, at least until the thread become accustomed to reading and treading. Each repeat of the pattern should be carefully checked, and the threads should be tied in a loose knot as soon as a section has been threaded.
1. Hedding or Threading is the step in which the warp thread is inserted through the heddle eyes.
2. Inserting of the fidded threads through the dents or spaces in between reeds

params.text: Tying warp ends onto the cloth-beam rod
The threading of the heddles and the sleying of the reed have been completed, the next is the tying of the warp ends onto the cloth-beam rod.
1. Unroll the ropes that lie around the beam warp and bring them around the beam and bring them up outside and on top of the breast beam, unrolling them to their full length.

2. Untie one of the groups of warp ends tied up close to the reed during sleying and pass it through the slit in the apron to determine if the warp is pulled through the reed far enough to tie a double knot.

3. Take the center group of warp ends and even the ends, gently easing any slack towards the front. The number of warp ends in each group is dependent on the distance between the holes in the apron. The threads should always slant in one direction.
4.Tie a single knot, pull the ends towards the reed, and tie a half-bow knot or, if necessary, a double knot.
5. Continue until all groups cross the loom have been tied.

params.text: The tie-up
To obtain a clear shed it is of the utmost importance that the harnesses be evenly tied to the lams and treadles

params.text: Preparing the shuttles

Before the weaving can be started, the shuttle must be filled. The ball or spool of warp may be placed in a box to facilitate winding. If a tube or spool is used, run a stick through the center of it and have someone hold the sticks in both hands.
Using the spool winder to wind the yarn to fill the tube

params.text: Testing the loom
Foot-loom counter balanced. Press the left treadle down to the floor. Note that the front harness sank or pulled down to the floor.
